comments.author: Herman Davis

comments.text:
Problem being, he only goes one way on this issue. Like most liberals, he 
ignores the fact that racism is not limited to whites. Just look at people 
like Al Sharpton. He is a racist. It is easy to point the finger at white 
males and leave it at that.

We all have to realize that of course there is racism. There always will 
be. That is human nature. We all look at why we are better than "them". 
They are fat, they are skinny, they like chocolate ice cream. And on and 
on. Racism is color blind. Every race is guilty of it.

So go look at a totally non-white company/corporation/whatever and see if 
there are racist emails there. You know you will find the same thing.

Most of us middle class white males really don't care about all this. We 
want stand up people who will pull their own weight. Skin color doesn't 
really matter. Character matters.

Jon once again blows it by saying "poverty is a choice". He is obviously 
meaning that it is not. Jon, for the most part it IS a choice. Fed by the 
federal gov't. I have not seen anybody being barred from school or from 
work sites forcing them into poverty. What we see is people being given 
handouts to the point they refuse to work but think they are owed a nice 
living by us who bust our butts everyday and pay taxes.﻿
comments.author: Feral Feline

comments.author: For Reasons of National Security

comments.text:
I stood with everyone in Ferguson but local towns giving tickets to raise 
funds is not a new thing. I moved to a small semi rural town mostly white. 
We were pulled over and ticketed for a tail light and later speeding doing 
40mph in a 35mph zone within 2 weeks of moving there and I am white. I 
would panic if a bulb went out and I always set my cruise control for the 
speed limits when driving locally through my town. They also were 
investigated by the FBI for arresting people without cause which I found 
out later (I assume white). I think it happens more than people know small 
towns trying to make up budget shortfalls in property value/tax losses 
since Wall Street & the economy fell happens. I remember when I was a teen 
there were certain towns you drove around cause cops pulled over kids 
regularly (at that time we called them pigs). BTW my ticket was the first 
ticket I've gotten in 20+yrs of driving cause I am a slow & careful driver. 
Especially now there seems like there is a problem with police and too much 
force toward the mentally ill and obviously always African Americans, but 
it is also toward many others. Looks like it is a sign of the times, and we 
would all be better off knowing our neighbors and police. Maybe back to the 
days of neighborhood policing and the police are your friend block parties. 
:)﻿
comments.author: Donna Rite

comments.author: erdoan001

comments.text:
Jon, I was a victim of racism one time. I remember a few years ago, I went 
trick or treating as Sportacus from Lazy Town. My Mom ordered an adult 
Sportacus costume for me off of Amazon. I was so excited! The night of 
trick or treating had finally arrived! I put on my Sportacus costume, and 
headed straight for Mrs. McCracken's house. She always gave out full sized 
Milky Way bars. Just as I was about at her door, I saw Scott Stephenson! : 
(   Scott yelled "Hey look everybody, it's Dorkacus!"  I got so mad that I 
did a roundhouse kick by Scott's face, but missed, and ripped my Sportacus 
pants! I was going commando, so as I was running home in tears, you could 
see my ButtCrackacus! : (﻿

comments.text:
*I recently had an unpleasant run-in with a bunch of racists on the 
Internet.* You know how you kind kind of deduce what a person's political 
position is by catching a few keywords from their dialogue? What struck me 
about these particular racists was how their dialogue was peppered with 
turns of phrase taken verbatim from some of these Fox News celebrities -- 
it is the language they use to rationalize their denial of 
institutionalized racism. It's like the Simpsons said about Fox News: "not 
racist, but #1 among racists."﻿

comments.author: wackydelly84

comments.text:
*The real issue with racism is that people don't even understand what it 
is, and think that it's something that can actually go away. It will only 
ever go away in the sense that stealing and murder goes away, in that it 
will be severely limited by fear of societal punishment, but every once in 
a while someone will still do it. I'm of course referring to outward racism 
- we're all racists on the inside, which is why racism on the outside will 
never go away completely. We all feel like killing someone at some point in 
our lives, but it's actually doing it that makes us murderers. We're all 
riding along that thin line until the right circumstances finally push us 
over the edge. Everyone alive today who claims to be a non-racist would 
have been a racist 90 years ago, it's all just social programming, but the 
hardware will always be in us to go either way*﻿

comments.author: Storie Grubb

comments.text:
+Tris A. I was told racism was on it's last leg nearly 30 years ago. It's 
looking stronger now than it ever was before. I suppose it suddenly became 
more open while in the years prior it was more discreetly vocalised by by 
racists in the media and office. After having a black president elected, it 
seems to cause an implosion of open racism. You can see it nearly explode 
in the first month he was in office. 

We didn't take care of racism, we just brushed it under a rug, and someone 
decided to lift the rug up to try and pull it from an unexpected person 
entering a white house.

comments.text:
let me preface this by stating that I am white.  Many of my friends use the 
term "clear" for how white I am.  HEY! Iodinate react to the sun very well. 
 :)  But i hear a lot about "if you can say it I can say it"  crap out 
there and it has got to be the most racist and inconsiderate response that 
I can think of to an objection to that word being said by a white person. 
 I just want to scream in their face "well as soon as your culture has been 
oppressed by another for CENTURIES in this country, you can pic a word that 
is only for you.  until then shut the fuck up"

See white people have a problem in tis country.  We don't deal with guilt 
very well and especially racial guilt.  And just like most people we try to 
minimize the guilt by "equalizing "tactics.  We will use the term racist 
against african americans as much as possible.  Because nothing minimizes 
guilt than you accuse the same behavior on your victims of from who you 
have that guilt.  Just like when your kids come "he hit me!"  He hit me 
first!"

And like with this N word shit.  The more "normal" we can make that word, 
the more numb we become to what it represents coming from the oppressors 
versos the oppressed.  

My only complaint is the number of times people say "n-word".  Every time 
its said guess what word pops in my head?  Yes you just made me use it in 
my head and then I feel bad.  

All kidding aside, before you minimize the atrocity that has occurred and 
still continues to occur in this country, don't automatically assume they 
feel no pain from the past when you joke and do as they do.  Oppression has 
pushed this culture into some unusual situations.  Situations that others 
can have no hope to understand.  Before you go screaming "Thug", "gangster" 
and think that these people are doing it tho themselves remember what their 
culture and ancestors have gone through and what they are currently going 
through.  

Would centuries of oppression cause you to be defensive and hostile to the 
oppressors race?  Yeah
Would centuries of oppression cause you to do things that are contrary to 
your character?  Yeah
Would centuries of oppression cause you to over-react when racial tension 
is high?  Yeah


There are many in this country that still think "whats the big deal if we 
have separate water fountains to drink from" now we know what the big deal 
is.
comments.author: Tomo Cured
